awd_titl_txt: Testing the Community Partnership Model through Lokono Language Documentation
awd_abstract_narration:
Broadening the participation of underrepresented groups in science can have transformative methodological consequences.  That is the hypothesis that Racquel Sapien Yamada of the University of Oklahoma (Norman) will test by implementing a new collaborative fieldwork model which extends the notion of community-inclusive field research by facilitating the documentation of one endangered language (Lokono) by native and heritage speakers of another (Kari'nja).

Kari'nja and Lokono (Arawak-arw) speakers live side-by-side in the Konomerume village of Suriname.  They often intermarry.  Data on Lokono and Karinja will elucidate the processes of language contact evidenced between these two languages.  The data will also help the place of Lokono (Arawakan family) and Kari'nja (Cariban family) within their respective language families. Yamada and her team will document, analyze, and describe aspects of Lokono to further investigate these issues.

This project is at the forefront of a greater movement to encourage members of endangered language communities to play more active roles in research that affects them.  The project team will provide training to build local infrastructure for future documentation.  A graduate student from the University of Oklahoma will receive field research and international experience through participation in the project.

The project is supported by co-funds from the National Science Foundation's International Science and Engineering Office.

por.por_cntn:
This project had two primary, overarching goals, one more focused on intellectual merit and the other more focused on broader impacts. In the area of intellectual merit, the project recorded first language speakers of Lokono (arw), an endangered Arawakan language of Suriname, speaking in several discourse genres. In the area of broader impacts, the project provided training to community members in methods and technology for language documentation. What made this project especially unique was that training for Lokono community members was provided by speakers of another endangered language of a different language family, Kari'nja (car, Cariban). In this way, community members were empowered to take ownership of and responsibility for a research project that has direct relevance to themselves and their goals for their languages.

 

Lokono is a severely endangered language spoken by fewer than 2,000 people in Suriname, Guyana, and French Guiana. Two dialects have been identified, Western Lokono as spoken in Guyana, and Eastern Lokono as spoken in Suriname and French Guiana. As a part of this project, recordings were made with first language speakers of Eastern Lokono in discourse genres that include personal narratives, traditional stories, original songs, and conversations. Genres were chosen both for their relevance to academic analysis and description as well as their importance to community members engaged in language reclamation activities. Both male and female speakers were recorded, and resulting texts were transcribed and translated.

 

Residing in Konomerume, Suriname, Lokono speakers live side-by-side with speakers of another endangered language of the region that is unrelated to Lokono, Kari'nja. Kari'nja speakers have been working with the PI for several years to document, analyze, describe, and revitalize their heritage language, and are well versed in methods of language documentation. They provided the primary training for their Lokono-speaking neighbors with a goal of documenting and strengthening both languages, as well as empowering the next generation of language workers to develop independent projects of their own design.

 

In the area of linguistic analysis, the Lokono speakers who contributed to this project were quite interested in earlier analyses of the language. Together, they and the PI were able to identify several areas of consistent divergence between prior analyses and the ways in which the language is used today. The PI will continue to investigate these phenomena with a goal of better understanding rapid language change in situations of contact and endangerment.

 

Despite the challenges presented by COVID-19 during the latter stages of the project and the recent unexpected death of one of the primary Lokono partners, the project was able to meet its stated goals. Additionally, two team members were able to travel to the US to co-present results of their work with the PI to two consecutive LSA Annual meetings, in 2018 and 2019. The analysis of recordings is ongoing, and the PI expects to publish additional results in the coming years. In addition, she continues to work with community members to develop materials in support of revitalization based on recordings made as a part of this project. Finally, and perhaps most importantly from a broader impacts perspective, Kari'nja and Lokono community members continue to work together to record additional speakers in different genres of speech.
